In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Mark A.
          Martucci, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4438
  Heard September 16, 2008 â€“ Filed September
24, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      Appellate Defender Elizabeth A. Franklin, of Columbia, for
        Appellant.
      Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
        General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
        and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia;
        and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Mark A.
  Martucci (Martucci) appeals his conviction for homicide by child abuse.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Martucci
  lived with Brandi Holder (Holder) and her two-year old son (Child) in July
  2002.Â  Child died on Wednesday, July 17, 2002.Â  Martucci and Holder were
  indicted for homicide by child abuse under Section 16-3-85 of the South
  Carolina Code.Â  Martucci did not appear for trial and was tried in his absence
  February 6-9, 2006.Â  The jury convicted Martucci, and his sentence was sealed.Â 
  On March 6, 2006, Martucci appeared in court and was sentenced to life in
  prison.
A
  priori, the Court embarks on a
  juridical journey encapsulating a temporal and spatial analysis of the
  evidentiary record.Â  Nurse Ladye Kelly testified that Martucci and John Parker
  (Parker) brought Child to the emergency room of Allen-Bennett Hospital.Â  Kelly declared Child appeared lifeless.Â  He â€œhad multiple bruises over most of his
  body.â€Â  She described â€œa very odd patternâ€ of marks on his face which appeared
  to be knuckle prints.Â  She stated Child â€œhad multiple bruises on his legs, on
  his arms.Â  His eyes were blackened.Â  He also had a place around his mouth that
  was scratches or abrasions . . . and had a lot of bruising.â€Â  Child had â€œa
  purple black mark that . . . covered most of his back.â€Â  Kelly substantiated
  the bruises â€œwere all in different stages of healing.Â  Some of them were very
  fresh looking dark-purplish blue colors.Â  Others were yellow, barely noticeable
  that had healed and were in between those two things.Â  Some were darker than
  others.Â  Some were lighter than others.â€Â  She recalled that Childâ€™s abdomen was
  â€œvery swollen.â€Â  He was â€œvery pale.Â  He was blue around the mouth,â€ which
  showed he had not been breathing.
Kelly
  assisted emergency room doctor Kevin Gregg in trying to revive Child, but they
  were unsuccessful.Â  Dr. Gregg asserted the Child was â€œfreshly dead.Â  He was
  coolerâ€”his temperature was cooler than 98.6, but it was warmer than room
  temperature.â€Â  Dr. Gregg recollected that Martucci and Parker told him about a
  â€œfour-wheeler ATV accidentâ€ earlier in the week.Â  Dr. Gregg declared they told
  him that Child was not wearing a helmet on an ATV and â€œflipped or was ejected
  out of the ATV, so the story went.Â  The story was that he looked okay after the
  injury so the family didnâ€™t feel a need to bring him to the ER to get
  checked.â€Â  Holder and Martucci advised Dr. Gregg that Child appeared weak and
  had vomited several times the day before.Â  Dr. Gregg professed Martucci claimed
  that he performed mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, and Child â€œbit him on the upper
  lip.â€Â  Dr. Gregg annunciated this story was implausible because â€œthat is
  something Iâ€™ve never seen before.Â  Iâ€™ve never head of it before.Â  When you do
  rescue breathing on somebody, they are unconscious.Â  And an unconscious person
  canâ€™t bite. . . . I donâ€™t understand why an unconscious boy would bite somebody
  on the lip. . . . If heâ€™s conscious, he doesnâ€™t need mouth to mouth
  resuscitation.â€Â  Dr. Gregg recalled that Martucci had an open cut on his lip,
  but he did not treat Martucciâ€™s injury.
Dr.
  Gregg opined Childâ€™s injuries were inconsistent with the kind of accident
  described.Â  He explained Child â€œhad bruises.Â  He didnâ€™t have cuts.Â  He didnâ€™t
  have abrasions.Â  He didnâ€™t have the usual signs of wear and tear you see on a
  two-and-a-half-year-old boy.Â  He didnâ€™t have skinned knees.Â  He didnâ€™t have
  scraped up palms from playing or rolling or falling off the porch.Â  He had
  bruises.â€Â  
John
  Parker (Parker) asseverated that he visited Martucci and Holderâ€™s home â€œ[f]rom
  time to time.â€Â  He saw Martucci interact with Child.Â  He testified without
  objection:

  Parker: There
    was an incident where we were in his living room and [Child] was crying.Â  And
    Mr. Martucci had told him on numerous occasions to . . . He was askedâ€”Mr.
    Martucci asked himâ€”or told him on numerous occasions to stop crying.Â  And
    [Child] did not do so.Â  He then proceeded to tape his mouth shut with tape.
  . . .
  There
    were episodes where he would be in the bathroom and Mr. Martucci would be
    giving him a bath.Â  I would hear [Child] crying.Â  And I would walk in to see
    what he was crying about and Mark would be pouring water over his head.Â  And
    [Child] would continue to keep crying.Â  He would tell him that crying is for
    pussys.Â  And he would dunk his head under water.Â  He did that on numerous
    occasions.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: When you say â€œdunk his head under water,â€ was it a quick dunk?
  Parker: No,
    maâ€™am.Â  Iâ€™d say, at least, a couple of seconds at a time.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: How was [Child] reacting to that?
  Parker: He
    would swallow water almost like he was choking on the water.Â  And then he would
    pull him up.Â  And then no soonerâ€”he would barely even catch his breath and he
    would do it again.
  . . .
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Did you witness anything else abusive?
  Parker: We
    were in the vanâ€”no, I take that back.Â  We were outside sometimes and then there
    was a couple of occasions in the inside of his house where he would be crying
    and Mr. Martucci would slap him in the face on both sides of his face.Â  
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Can you sort of demonstrate in some way what youâ€™re talking about?Â 
    What kind of slap or force was used?
  Parker: The
    only way I can describe it is the way a person would smack a dog to make them
    mean, back and forth.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Thatâ€™s what he did to [Childâ€™s] head?
  Parker: Yes,
    maâ€™am.Â  Iâ€™ve seen him grab his face like that when he wouldnâ€™t stop crying and
    try to tell him to be quiet.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Did you ever see bruises or marks on [Child]?
  Parker: I
    did notice the bruises on his face from the way he was grabbing him.Â  And I
    believe I did notice the bite on his wrist.Â  Theyâ€”it did seem that they went
    out of their way to make sure he kept clothes on.Â  I very rarely seen him
    without clothes, except for the incidents in the bathroom.

Dr.
    Michael Eugene Ward, Greenville Countyâ€™s chief medical examiner, was called to
    the hospital soon after Child was pronounced dead.Â  He declared:

  On
    initial examination at Allen Bennett Hospital, there were numerous bruises to
    [Child] about the face, the chest, the back, and the extremities.Â  There were
    injuries that were present around the perineum or the penis, and to one of the
    arms that were especially disconcerting to us.Â  And so we took samples of them
    at that time.

Dr.
  Ward performed an autopsy on Child.Â  Photographs of Child and his internal
  organs were admitted into evidence over Martucciâ€™s objection.Â  Dr. Ward used
  the photographs to explain Childâ€™s injuries:

  This is
    a photograph of the left back leg of [Child].Â  This is right in the crux of the
    leg.Â  And, as you can see, there are these bruises and superficial abrasions of
    the skin running in a linear fashion across the skin.Â  These indicating that
    this is a result of blunt injury.
  So itâ€™s
    not a sharp injury that you would expect from a knife or from some sort of
    cutting instrument.Â  And itâ€™s not from a penetrating injury like a gunshot
    wound, but itâ€™s a blunt injury where the skin is compressed and thereâ€™s
    disruption of underlying blood vessels resulting in a bruise, as well as a
    superficial abrasion or a scratching of the skin.
  So this
    is linear injuries or line-shaped contusions to the back of [Childâ€™s] leg.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Dr. Ward, in your experience and training, are there any particular
    mechanisms of inflicting such a linear bruise?
  Dr.
    Ward: There are.Â  There are numerous instruments that can be used that will cause
    a linear-type bruise.Â  Generally, they are things that are longer than they are
    wide.Â  Certain things can beâ€”they can be cords.Â  They can be belts or even
    fingers if a slap is applied in a hard enough fashion that create these linear
    and sort of semi-circular type bruises as with this.
  . . .
  This is
    a photograph of the perineal region of the body of [Child].Â  This is the
    abdomen here, the pelvis, the penis, and the scrotum.Â  Here at the base of the
    penis is a bruise, a sort of butterfly-shaped, if you will, bruise
    approximately one and a half inch in greatest dimension.Â  Thereâ€™s a smaller
    bruise in this region here.
  And
    right here at the base of the penis where the skin of the penis attaches to the
    pelvic skin, thereâ€™s a superficial laceration or tear of the skin in this
    region.Â  I took microscopic sectionsâ€”at the time of autopsy, I took microscopic
    sections of the skin through this region here.Â  It demonstrated acute
    hemorrhage or bleeding into the skin.Â  But it indicated that there was no
    evidence of any healing.Â  There was no inflammation.Â  There was no granulation
    tissue.Â  There was no evidence of repair to this region here or here.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: And what did that indicate to you?
  Dr.
    Ward: That is was a recent injury only aâ€”no more than a few hours old.Â  And as
    we will see with other injuries that there were, there wasâ€”which have evidence
    of healing that this act most very likely occurred at a different time than the
    other injuriesâ€”some other injuries.Â  This is the result of blunt trauma. Â I
    believe that this is a blunt injury to this region here with superficial
    tearing of adjacent skin.
  . . .
  This is
    a photograph taken at the time of autopsy showing the intraabdominal cavity of
    [Child].Â  There were bruises on the outer surface of the skin.Â  As we dissected
    beneath, there wasâ€”there were bruising beneath the skin and above the muscles
    of the abdomen.
  When we
    reflected those muscles of the abdomen, we were able to demonstrate that there
    was over 250 milliliters of blood present in the peritoneal cavity or in the
    abdominal cavity.Â  350 milliliters is about the size of a can of Coke.Â  So this
    is almost the amount of blood thatâ€™s in a can of Coke or a little bit less than
    that.
  This is
    the small intestine here.Â  And this is the large intestine.Â  As you can see,
    thereâ€™s a space between here that should not normally be.Â  Thereâ€™s a fatty
    ligament that normally attaches this large intestine to the underlying
    structures of the abdomen.Â  This has been torn.Â  Itâ€™s been torn away from the
    underlying surface of the large intestine.Â  And in this region here, there is
    blood that is hemorrhaged within the outer surface of the large intestine, as
    well asâ€”
  . . .
  Stateâ€™s
    Exhibit No. 13, again, demonstrates the tearing of the ligament that normally
    attaches the large intestine to the stomach demonstrating that it has been torn
    away along this broad surface of the transverse colon, hemorrhage within the
    outer surface of the colon, as well as hemorrhage deep down in the structures
    of the abdomen.Â  Within this region here, itâ€™s the head of the pancreas.Â  There
    have been trauma and hemorrhage to the head of the pancreas with the soft
    tissue surrounding the pancreas with hemorrhage. 
  And the
    interesting thing about this injury is that when I took microscopic sections
    from this region, it did show evidence of healing, that there were
    evidenceâ€”there were areas that showed not only acute hemorrhage, but there were
    other areas that showed hemorrhage that had been there for a period of time,
    several hours to a couple of days such that the body had started to react to
    this injury.Â  It had started to try to repair it.Â  And there wasâ€”there were
    fibrous tissues being laid down.Â  There were new blood vessels there.Â  There
    were cells that come in and try to clean up this blood.
  So we
    have two different ages of trauma here in the abdomen.Â  Weâ€™ve got some that
    shows evidence of healing, and some that show no evidence of healing and only
    fresh blood.
  . . .
  The
    blunt injuries to [Childâ€™s] gastrointestinal system would, basically, cause his
    small and large intestine to no longer function in the way that we know it to
    do.Â  The small intestine, basically, takes food, water, and other products from
    the stomach and allows it to pass and begin to digest on its way down to the
    large intestine.Â  When you traumatize the small intestine, as [Child] had with
    tearing of the mucosa, then the musclesâ€”the smooth muscles in the small
    intestine are no longer going to work together to move things down the system.Â 
    So theyâ€™re going to back up.Â  
  And the
    most common presentation of someone with trauma to the small intestine like
    that and no longer moving fluids out would be vomiting, in that anything that
    goes in is going to sit on the stomach and not be able to be passed down.Â  The
    pressure is going to be increased.Â  And then the person would have nausea and
    vomiting.Â  Certainly, I would expect it to be, obviously fairly painful in that
    he may even show some guarding and not want you to touch his stomach.

Elizabeth
  Venesky (Venesky) lived next door to Martucci and Holder.Â  Her husband took two
  pictures of her and Child while he visited their house on June 20, 2002.Â  In
  the pictures, Child was not wearing a shirt.Â  Dr. Ward discussed:

  These
    bruises here [in Veneskyâ€™s pictures] are notâ€”although theyâ€™re in the same
    location, theyâ€™re not the same bruises that we saw at the time of autopsy.Â  So
    he has bruises here at this time.Â  He has separate and distinct bruises in
    virtually the same place at the time of autopsy.

ISSUES

  
    I.
    Did trial judge err in admitting
  autopsy photographs of Child’s internal organs and other injuries?
  
  
    II. 
    Did the trial judge err in admitting
  evidence of prior incidents of alleged abuse of Child by Martucci in the weeks
  immediately preceding his death?
  
  
    III.
    Did the trial judge err in
  admitting evidence of Martucci’s character, specifically Parker’s testimony
  that Martucci had a temper and had pistols in the house?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 472, 613 S.E.2d 381, 384 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State
      v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Wood,
  362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004)); State v. Landis,
  362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Abdullah,
  357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThis court is bound
  by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€Â  Preslar,
  364 S.C. at 472, 613 S.E.2d at 384; accord State v. Baccus, 367
  S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006) (citing State v. Quattlebaum,

  occurred.Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745 (2001), overruled
    on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494
  (2005); Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435; State v. Adams, 354
  S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Under this theory, it is important
  that the temporal proximity of the prior bad act be closely related to the
  charged crime.Â  Hough, 325 S.C. 88, 480 S.E.2d 77.Â  Even if the evidence
  is relevant under this theory, prior to admission the trial judge should
  determine whether its probative value clearly outweighs any unfair prejudice.
  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Bolden, 303 S.C. 41, 398 S.E.2d 494 (1990).
Martucci
  argues the prior incidents were neither factually nor temporally related to the
  charged crime.Â  In this case, the time period and similarity of the incidents
  involved must be examined overall because of the nature of the crime charged.Â 
  The overall view of the facts provides the context in which the crime occurred
  and demonstrates the culminating impact on Child.Â  The incidents were relevant
  to establishing Martucciâ€™s state of mind and whether or not he manifested an
  extreme indifference to human life.Â  The alleged child abuse occurred in the
  month and a half to several weeks before the fatal trauma was inflicted.Â  The
  evidence was necessary to establish the crime charged.Â  Its admission was essential
  and relevant to a full presentation of the evidence in this case.Â  The
  testimony regarding the prior bad acts was relevant to show the complete, whole
  story relating to the charge of homicide by child abuse.Â  Moreover, the
  probative value of the evidence outweighed its prejudicial effect.Â  See Owens,
  346 S.C. at 653, 552 S.E.2d at 753.Â  The trial judge did not err in admitting
  the evidence of alleged prior abuse pursuant to the res gestae doctrine.
III. Parkerâ€™s
  Â testimony of Martucciâ€™s character
Martucci
  argues the trial judge committed reversible error in allowing Parkerâ€™s
  testimony about his temper and that he had pistols in the house.Â  He contends
  this evidence improperly introduced his bad character to the jury and was
  inadmissible under State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  We
  disagree.
Parker
  witnessed several occasions when Martucci abused Child while he stayed at the
  house.Â  Parker testified that when Martucci abused Child, â€œit would upset me to
  the point to where I would have to walk outside.Â  I couldnâ€™t listen to it
  anymore.â€Â  On direct examination, the Assistant Solicitor asked Parker:

  Assistant
    Solicitor: Did you ever think about trying to call for help for [Child]?
  Parker: I
    thought about it, yes, maâ€™am.Â  Me and Mr. Martucci hadâ€”we had had conflicts in
    the past.Â  And I knew of his temper from hanging out with him a lotâ€”
  Defense
    Counsel: Your Honor, I would object to any character evidence of Mr. Martucci.
  The
    Court: Iâ€™ll allow this.Â  Go ahead.
  Parker: We
    hadâ€”I knew of his attitude.Â  I knew he had pistols in the house.Â  I knew that
    heâ€”we had had conflicts in the past to the pointâ€”we hadâ€”there was one episode
    in Myrtle Beach to where me and a few friends of mine were down there as well
    asâ€”
  Defense
    Counsel: Your Honor, I hate to objectâ€”
  The
    Court: Yes.Â  This is getting a little bit too far now, Solicitor.
  Assistant
    Solicitor: Your Honor, I will say that this is relevant to his state of mind
    andâ€”
  The
    Court: All right.Â  Iâ€™m going to stop it here.Â  I think itâ€™s gone far enough.Â 
    Move on, please.

Parkerâ€™s
  direct examination continued.Â  Parker averred he was afraid of Martucci because
  of prior incidents.Â  Parker noted he was â€œpretty smallâ€ in comparison to
  Martucci.Â  Parker said he did not get help because, â€œI was afraid of him and I
  knew theâ€”what could happen scared me.â€
Where
  a defendant objects and the objection is sustained but he does not move to
  strike the evidence, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State
    v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 404, 410, 458 S.E.2d 61, 65 (Ct. App. 1995) (no issue
  is preserved for appeal where the court sustains a partyâ€™s objection to
  improper testimony and the party does not move to strike the testimony); State
    v. Wingo, 304 S.C. 173, 177-78, 403 S.E.2d 322, 325 (Ct. App. 1991) (a
  motion to strike is necessary where a question is answered before an objection
  has been interposed, even though the objection is sustained); see also State
    v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 75, 502 S.E.2d 63, 73, 76 (1998) (any prejudice to
  the defendant could have been removed if the defendant had requested the trial
  judge to strike the objected-to testimony and to give a curative instruction to
  the jury).Â  
In
  the case at bar, Martucci objected to Parkerâ€™s testimony about the presence of
  guns in the house and a prior incident in Myrtle Beach.Â  The trial judge
  sustained the objection by stating, â€œitâ€™s gone far enough.â€Â  He then instructed
  the Assistant Solicitor to â€œmove on.â€Â  Martucci failed to request the trial
  judge either strike the objectionable testimony or to instruct the jury to
  disregard the reference, and he did not move for a mistrial.Â  His failure to
  request appropriate relief precludes appellate review of this issue.Â  Id.
When
  Parker later testified about his fear of Martucci based on prior incidents and
  because he knew â€œwhat could happen to me,â€ there was no objection.Â  Because the
  jury heard this other evidence, the fact they heard the previous testimony was
  not prejudicial to Martucci.Â  See Haselden, 353 S.C. at 196, 577
  S.E.2d at 448 (stating the erroneous admission of prior bad act evidence is
  harmless beyond a reasonable doubt if its impact is minimal in the context of
  the entire record); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d
  859, 862 (1993) (finding any error in the admission of evidence cumulative to
  other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).
Parkerâ€™s
  testimony was an isolated comment regarding Martucciâ€™s temper and his
  possession of pistols that did not prejudice Martucci.Â  The State did not
  attempt to introduce evidence of any prior convictions or otherwise highlight
  his character in this regard.Â  See State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1,
  515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (determining law enforcement agentâ€™s isolated testimony
  that he compared defendantâ€™s fingerprints with a fingerprint card agency had on
  record was not so prejudicial to defendant as to warrant a mistrial because it
  was questionable whether jury drew connection between fingerprint card and
  defendantâ€™s prior criminal activity); State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 476
  S.E.2d 903 (1996) (recognizing appellantâ€™s possible drug dealing was merely
  suggested and no testimony was presented concerning such behavior); State v.
    Robinson, 238 S.C. 140, 119 S.E.2d 671 (1961), overruled on other
      grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991)
  (holding that, even if the testimony created the inference in the juryâ€™s mind
  that the accused had committed another crime, the State never attempted to
  prove the accused had been convicted of some other crime); State v. Creech,
  314 S.C. 76, 81-82, 441 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding trial judge
  did not abuse his discretion in denying defendantâ€™s motion for a mistrial when
  officer testified that he obtained warrants for defendantâ€™s arrest and
  contacted â€œthe Probation Officerâ€).Â  Accordingly, Martucci is not entitled to a
  new trial.
IV.Â  Harmless Error
Assuming, arguendo, that the trial judge did err in admitting Parkerâ€™s testimony,
  such error was harmless.Â  Whether an error is harmless depends on the
  circumstances of the particular case.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 63,
  584 S.E.2d 893, 897 (2003); Taylor, 333 S.C. at 172, 508 S.E.2d at 876; State
    v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 562, 575 S.E.2d 77, 83 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œNo
  definite rule of law governs this finding; rather, the materiality and
  prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to
  the entire case.â€Â  Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151.
Error
  is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the
  trial.Â  In re Harvey, 355 S.C. at 63, 584 S.E.2d at 897; Mitchell,
  286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 610,
  486 S.E.2d 762, 764 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set
  aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  Sherard,
  303 S.C. at 176, 399 S.E.2d at 597; Adams, 354 S.C. at 380-81, 580
  S.E.2d at 795.Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the
  trial is harmless when guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence
  such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State v. Bailey,
  298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989).Â  The admission of improper evidence
  is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.Â  State
    v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 329, 247 S.E.2d 334, 337 (1978); Weaverling,
  337 S.C. at 471, 523 S.E.2d at 793; see also State v. Williams,
  321 S.C. 455, 463, 469 S.E.2d 49, 54 (1996) (instructing that error in
  admission of evidence is harmless where it is cumulative to other evidence
  which is properly admitted).
There
  was overwhelming and independent evidence of Martucciâ€™s guilt.Â  Parker
  testified about Martucciâ€™s prior abuse of Child and that Martucci was the last
  person with Child before he died.Â  Martucci lied to the police and hospital
  personnel about the cause of Childâ€™s injuries.Â  Holder told the police about
  Martucciâ€™s physical abuse of Child just before his death.Â  This evidence,
  together with other physical evidence in this case, clearly demonstrates
  Martucciâ€™s guilt of homicide by child abuse was conclusively proven by
  competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion could be reached.Â 
  Given this substantial and overwhelming evidence of Martucciâ€™s guilt, the
  challenged evidence was cumulative and its admission is not a ground for
  reversal.Â  Baccus, 367 S.C. at 55-56, 625 S.E.2d at 224; Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795.
There
  was other evidence demonstrating Parkerâ€™s fear of Martucci which was admitted
  without objection.Â  Deputy Wesley Smith interviewed Parker at the law
  enforcement center on the day of Childâ€™s death.Â  Smith testified Parker â€œwas
  cooperative.Â  He really acted like he was scared of Mr. Martucci and what his
  involvement in the case would be and what would happen to him.â€Â  Smith vouched
  Parker â€œwas always kind of hesitantâ€ about answering questions.Â  He advanced
  Parker â€œcried someâ€ during the interview because he told him that he was afraid
  of Martucci.Â  See State v. Johnson, 298 S.C. 496, 498, 381 S.E.2d
  732, 733 (1989) (stating admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is
  merely cumulative to other evidence); Broaddus, 361 S.C. at 542, 605
  S.E.2d at 583-84 (holding error in admission of drug evidence was harmless
  where it was cumulative to other unobjected-to testimony at trial regarding
  drug use and drug dealing); State v. Richardson, 358 S.C. 586, 596-97,
  595 S.E.2d 858, 863 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding that even if the challenged
  testimony constituted improper â€œcharacter evidence,â€ any error in its admission
  was harmless where the testimony was cumulative to other similar testimony that
  was admitted without objection); see also State v. Brown, 344
  S.C. 70, 75, 543 S.E.2d 552, 555 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding any error in
  admitting evidence of murder defendantâ€™s violent character was harmless as
  properly admitted evidence of the defendantâ€™s use of force during his argument
  with victim the previous day clearly demonstrated defendantâ€™s propensity to
  become violent).
If
  the admission of Parkerâ€™s testimony was erroneous, it was clearly harmless
  beyond a reasonable doubt because its impact was minimal in context of the
  entire record.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold the trial court properly admitted autopsy photographs which were relevant
  to prove Child was abused, that the abuse was the cause of his death, and the
  abuse manifested an extreme indifference to human life, all of which support
  the charge for which Martucci was under indictment.Â  The evidence of Martucciâ€™s
  prior abuse of Child was admissible to show intent, the identity of the abuser,
  the absence of mistake or accident, and a common scheme or plan of abuse.Â  We determine
  any error in the admission of Parkerâ€™s testimony about Martucciâ€™s character is
  not preserved.Â  Had the issue been preserved, the testimony would be cumulative
  to unobjected-to testimony and concomitantly harmless.
Accordingly,
  Martucciâ€™s conviction is
 AFFIRMED.Â  
WILLIAMS
  and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Charles
          Bickerstaff, M.D. and Barbara Magera, M.D., Appellants,
        v.
        Roger Prevost d/b/a
        Prevost Construction, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4439
  Heard June 4, 2008 â€“ Filed September 25,
2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled January
7, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Patrick J. McDonald and Steven L. Smith, both of Charleston, for
          Appellants.
        Frank M. Cisa, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.: Â Charles Bickerstaff and
  Barbara Magera (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s award of
  prejudgment interest to Roger Prevost and Prevost Construction Company
  (Prevost). Â We affirm. 
FACTS
Appellants entered
  into a contract with Prevost for interior remodeling of their home.Â  The home
  experienced significant water damage when a broken water line to the washing
  machine flooded the first floor of the residence.Â  Thereafter, Appellants
  brought an action against Prevost alleging negligence and breach of implied
  warranty of workmanship as a part of the remodeling work.Â  Prevost answered
  Appellantsâ€™ complaint, and counterclaimed for breach of contract, implied
  contract/quantum meruit, and foreclosure of its previously filed mechanicâ€™s
  lien. Â Included in Prevostâ€™s counterclaims was a request for interest on any
  payment due pursuant to the contract, at the agreed-upon â€œdaily rate of 1%.â€ 
A jury trial
  resulted in a verdict in favor of Prevost in the amount of $6,437.62. Â After
  the jury had been excused, Prevost made a post-trial motion for attorneysâ€™ fees
  and prejudgment interest under the contract.Â  The contractual provision at
  issue stated:Â  â€œPayment due under this Contract but not paid shall incur a
  daily interest rate of 1% from the date the payment is due.â€Â  The circuit court
  took the matter under advisement and then issued an order awarding Prevost
  prejudgment interest as defined under the contract.Â  The award of prejudgment
  interest is the only issue before us on appeal. Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Entitlement to
  Prejudgment Interest/Question of Fact for the Jury
Appellants contend
  the issue of prejudgment interest was a question of fact that should have been
  submitted to the jury.Â  Additionally, Appellants contend the circuit courtâ€™s
  award of prejudgment interest to Prevost under the contract was in error.Â  We
  disagree.
Initially, we note
  neither party appears to have argued during the presentation of evidence that
  the issue of prejudgment interest should be submitted to the jury.Â  The circuit
  court issued a post-judgment order granting Prevost prejudgment interest as
  specified in the contract, but did not make a finding as to whether the
  prejudgment interest was a question of law or fact.[1]Â 
  Appellants made no Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment
  requesting the court rule on its finding.Â  However, Appellantsâ€™ argument also
  fails on the merits.Â  It is well settled in this state that the award of
  prejudgment interest is a function of the trial court, and has never been held
  to be an issue of fact requiring its submission in a jury trial.Â  See Smith-Hunter
    Constr. Co. v. Hopson, 365 S.C. 125, 616 S.E.2d 419 (2005); Babb v.
      Rothrock, 310 S.C. 350, 426 S.E.2d 789 (1993).Â  
South Carolina law permits
  prejudgment interest on obligations to pay money from the time when, either by
  agreement of the parties or operation of law, the payment is demandable and if
  the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.Â  Smith-Hunter,
  365 S.C. at 128, 616 S.E.2d at 421 (citing Babb v. Rothrock, 310 S.C.
  350, 426 S.E.2d 789 (1993)). Â As explained in a recent supreme court case, â€œprejudgment interest is allowed on a claim of
  liquidated damages; i.e., the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to
  certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously
  agreed to by the parties . . . [t]he fact that the amount due is disputed by
  the opposing party does not render the claim unliquidated for the purposes of
  an award of prejudgment interest.â€Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 133,
  631 S.E.2d 252, 258-59 (2006). Â Thus, â€œ[t]he proper test for determining
  whether prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether or not the measure of
  recovery, not necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by conditions
  existing at the time the claim arose.â€ Â Smith-Hunter, 365 S.C. at 128,
  616 S.E.2d at 421.
Here, Appellants
  and Prevost entered into a contract found by the circuit court to be for a
  definite amount of $27,865; therefore, the measure of recovery was fixed by
  conditions existing at the time the claim arose.Â  It is of no consequence that
  each party claimed damages under the contract, or that the jury returned a
  verdict for less than the liquidated damages requested by Prevost.Â  Therefore,
  we find the circuit court properly considered the applicable law on prejudgment
  interest, and was correct in its determination that Prevost is entitled to
  interest on the amount of damages awarded by the jury. 
II. Consumer Protection
  Code Prohibits the Interest Rate under the Contract; Interest Rate Is Punitive
  In Nature, and Violates the Constitution and the Public Policy of This State
Appellants
  next contend the South Carolina Consumer Protection Code prohibits the imposition
  of interest in excess of twelve percent per annum.Â  Additionally, they maintain
  the award of interest at the rate of one percent per day was grossly
  disproportionate to the amount of the principal, making it punitive in nature,
  and violative of the United States Constitution and the public policy of this
  state.Â  Appellants present these arguments for the very first time on appeal.Â 
  As a result, they were not ruled upon by the circuit court, and are not
  preserved for our review.Â  See Hubbard v. Rowe, 192 S.C. 12, 5
  S.E.2d 187 (1939) (stating the questions presented for appellate review must
  first have been fairly and properly raised in the circuit court and passed upon
  by that court); see also State v. Powers, 331 S.C. 37, 501
  S.E.2d 116 (1998) (finding constitutional arguments are no exception to the
  rule, and if not raised to the trial court are deemed waived on appeal).
AFFIRMED.[2] 
KONDUROS, J.,
  concurs.Â  SHORT, J., concurs in part, dissents in part in a separate
  opinion.
SHORT,
  J., (concurring in part, dissenting in part):Â  I concur in part and respectfully dissent in part.
I agree with the majority that Appellantsâ€™ Consumer
  Protection Code and constitutional arguments are not preserved for review.Â 
  However, I find the issue of whether the prejudgment interest should have been
  presented to the jury is not preserved for review.[3]Â  Furthermore, I would
  remand the action for the trial court to set the amount of prejudgment
  interest.
As noted by the
  majority in footnote 2, the issue of the amount of interest due is still
  unsettled.Â  As there is something remaining to be done prior to full resolution
  of this case, I would remand to the Honorable Deadra L. Jefferson for a hearing
  to determine the amount of prejudgment interest to award Prevost. Â See TranSouth
    Finâ€™l Corp. v. Cochran, 324 S.C. 290, 297, 478 S.E.2d 63, 66-67 (Ct. App.
  1996) (remanding for an additional hearing to determine the amount of the final
  judgment where the parties disputed, inter alia, the prejudgment
  interest due on an undisputed principal amount due).Â  See generally Adams
    v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 303 S.C. 251, 255,
  399 S.E.2d 788, 790 (Ct. App. 1990) (remanding case due to legal error because
  agency failed to make critical findings).
The
  inequity arising from an award of prejudgment interest calculated by
  multiplying one percent of the judgment by 725, as is the case here as
  calculated by the majority, and the partiesâ€™ confusion as to the amount of the
  judgment including prejudgment interest, requires me to respectfully concur in
part and dissent in part.[4]


[1] It is presumably implicit in its order granting
interest that the court found this issue to be a question of law.
[2] We note this court is not blind to the inequity that
  results from the imposition of the rate of one percent daily interest on this
  jury award.Â  The circuit court found interest was due under the contract
  beginning on June 1, 2004, a finding that was not appealed, and the jury award
  of $6,437.62 in damages occurred 725 days later, on May 26, 2006.Â  If the
  provision is interpreted to provide prejudgment interest on any payment due
  under the contract as a one percent daily penalty fee, i.e. taking an amount of
  one percent of the award due each day according to the circuit courtâ€™s order,
  then the prejudgment interest due on the award would be $46,672.75 (calculated
  simply by multiplying one percent of the award by 725).Â  However, if the
  provision is interpreted to provide daily one percent compounding interest, then the prejudgment interest due on the award would be $8,744,225.12
  (calculated by multiplying the $6,437.62 award, by 1.01 to the 725th power).Â 
  The circuit courtâ€™s order does not set out a method for calculating the
  interest, nor does it quote the actual dollar interest award.Â  Appellants
  estimate the interest at $60,000-plus, failing to explain how they arrived at
  that number, and Prevost does not state a number in its brief.Â  Although the
  contractual interest rate term itself is potentially ambiguous, as opposed to
  the academic argument of entitlement to prejudgment interest, and although a
  court could find alternatively that the term is unconscionable or would lead to
  an absurd result, we are nonetheless confronted with the insurmountable
  obstacle that Appellants neither made these arguments below, nor presented them
  to us on appeal.Â  See Iâ€™On v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406,
  526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (stating an appellate court may affirm for any reason
  appearing in the record, but may reverse only for a reason raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial court and argued on appeal); see also Langley
    v. Boyter, 284 S.C. 162, 181, 325 S.E.2d 550, 561 (Ct. App. 1984) revâ€™d
      on other grounds, 286 S.C. 85, 332 S.E.2d 100 (1985) (â€œ[A]ppellate courts
  in this state, like well-behaved children, do not speak unless spoken to and do
  not answer questions they are not asked.â€); contra State v. Forrester,
  343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001) (addressing an issue sua sponte); 15 SC
  Juris Appeal and Error Â§Â§71-73 (1992 and Supp. 2007) (outlining the rules and
exceptions for preserving and presenting error for appellate review).Â  
[3] After the jury returned its verdict, Appellants
  argued the prejudgment interest rate was a matter for the jury.Â  The trial
  judge stated:Â  â€œI am inclined to believe, although Iâ€™m not fixed in that
  opinion, that the one percent that would be due on the debt is a matter of law
  for the Court.â€Â  The judge required the parties to submit orders on the issue
  of, inter alia, prejudgment interest.Â  In the final order, the court
  concluded Prevost was entitled to prejudgment interest at the contract rate
  without ruling on the issue of whether the interest should have been decided by
  the jury.Â  Appellants filed no post-trial motions.Â  See Elam v. South
    Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004)
  (stating a party must file a motion to reconsider when an issue has been
  raised, but not ruled on, to preserve issue for appellate review).
[4] I recognize parties are free to contract for higher
  interest rates within legal limits.Â  See Taylor, Cotton &
    Ridley, Inc. v. Okatie Hotel Group, 372 S.C. 89, 99, 641 S.E.2d 459, 464
  (Ct. App. 2007).Â  However, the prejudgment interest rate here is clearly beyond
  any legal rate of interest and is unconscionable.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(A)
  (Supp. 2007) (setting legal rate of interest on accounts stated at 8.75 percent
  per annum).
